feed.title: Tips and Tricks for Provision-ISR Installers

entry.title: About
entry.content:
Welcome!


The Odessia is an online fantasy adventure about a girl called Odessa and her companion, a cat called Praetorius Pathfinder XII, or Trousers for short.  Their journey begins when Odessa decides to cross Bridge #90 to see The Man in the Mountain

Please also have a look at the information about copyright and collaboration.


The Odessia by Alexander J Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://www.theodessia.com.

You are welcome to share and use these stories in your works as long as you link back to http://www.theodessia.com.

Feel free to get in touch via email, Facebook, Google+, or Twitter

If you'd like to donate to this project:

TeamViewer[edit]

We use a licensed version of TeamViewer 10.
If your client (or his customer) does not have TeamViewer installed when you start a support call, he will probably need to install it.

Exit TeamViewer[edit]

Check the Taskbar in the bottom-right corner of the desktop to see if a version of TeamViewer other than 10 is running.
If it is running, right-click the TeamViewer mini-icon and select Exit.

Install the Centrevision TeamViewer QuickSupport Client[edit]

  1. Go to http://www.centrevision.com.au.
  2. Go to Support.
  3. Click the large blue text that reads, "For Support please click here".
If all goes well, the QuickSupport client will be downloaded and will run. It will generate a session code and the client's computer will become available.

Watch out for Security Software[edit]

On some computers, the local anti-virus or anti-malware program will block the download or interfere with the running of the Teamviewer client.
If the client can't get it started, advise him to temporarily switch off the malware scanner.

Start a Teamviewer Session[edit]

Gather Key Information[edit]

Refer to this blog post to get yourself oriented on a client's network.

entry.title: The Tale of the DVR That Suddenly Stopped Recording One Day
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

Once upon a time there was a DVR that mysteriously stopped recording one day.

Initial Investigation

When Technical Support looked up the recorded footage, he found that indeed it had recorded nothing for the past couple of weeks.

Technical Support inspected the hard drive, but it seemed to be running just fine:

In the Schedule Settings, both Motion and Sensor were running 24/7 on all channels:

Initial Diagnosis

Technical Support and the client thought that the HDD might be at fault, and made preliminary arrangements to replace it.  However, Technical Support could not account for the following observations:
  1. The HDD was shown as “Formatted”, a generally strong indicator of HDD health.


  1. The DVR could be induced to record manually, with the extra space taken up by the test recording reflected in the free-to-used space ratio in the Disk Management page.

All this raised doubts in the mind of Technical Support, who emailed Boss Man for a second opinion.

Revised Diagnosis and Solution

One fresh pair of eyes later, the problem was spotted.  For some reason, although the DVR was set to record in response to any motion detected, Motion Detection itself had been turned off on all the channels!

And the Log showed that as soon as this setting was changed, recording stopped:

From there, it was a simple matter of enabling Motion Detection...

Et voila! Motion recording returned to normal:

entry.title: How To Remotely View Provision-ISR CCTV in Your Browser
entry.content:
How to remotely view Provision-ISR CCTV in your browser
You can log into a Provision-ISR DVR or NVR or even a stand-alone IP camera via Internet Explorer or Firefox on Windows, or Safari on MacOSX.

Windows 7/8/10

NOTE ON WINDOWS 10: Use the old Internet Explorer, not Microsoft Edge.


Internet Explorer

Make sure that your Security Settings allow the ActiveX plug-in.

Next, go to the external IP or DDNS address provided by your installer.

You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.


Firefox

Your CCTV system’s web address will take you to a light-blue page with a large download button and a refresh button.  Click the download button to download the file Webclient.exe.

Close Firefox.

Open Windows Explorer, locate the downloaded Webclient.exe and run it.

A terminal window will open briefly and then close again.

Re-open Firefox and return to your CCTV system’s web address.  Now you should receive a pop-up notification asking for permission to run an ActiveX control.

Finally, refresh the page.

You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.


Mac OSX

Safari is the only browser on Mac OSX that consistently allows the necessary ActiveX controls for logging into a Provision-ISR system, although it is theoretically possible on Firefox too.
Instructions for Mac OSX will be made available soon.

Linux

There is currently no way to log into a Provision-ISR system via a browser on Linux, as the ActiveX controls necessary are not available for Linux.  Your best bet is to run Internet Explorer or Firefox in a Windows Virtualbox.  A theoretical possibility is to run Internet Explorer in Wine, but this has not been done to date with any success.

entry.title: How To Take a Screenshot of Recorded Footage on a Provision-ISR DVR/NVR
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

The following guide uses the free open source video player VLC to conveniently extract a still image from footage recorded on a Provision-ISR video recorder, and also meets the Victorian legal standard for video evidence admissible in court.


Backup as “DVR”
Convert
Extract Still Image in VLC

Backup as “DVR”

Insert a USB drive into one of the USB ports on the DVR/NVR.


Select “Backup” from the main menu.


Select the Event and click Backup.




In “Save File Type” you can select either DVR or AVI.
DVR is encoded with a proprietary codec that can be played only with the Backup Player.  This open complies with Victorian legal requirements for admissibility of video evidence.
AVI is an open format and does not comply with Victorian legal requirements for admissibility of video evidence, but for the purposes of reviewing footage and extracting stills it is very convenient.


Convert

Super Player, which can be bundled with the DVR export option, has an option to convert footage to AVI.


Extract Still Image in VLC

When you play the footage, you can extract a still image at the desired point.



You will find the snapshot in the Pictures folder.
I reached for the sun block. For a spring morning, it was freakishly hot and it would rise to 32 by the afternoon, the highest ever temperature for a Grand Final, I was later told. Melbourne CCTV

entry.title: How To Attach the Bracket to a Provision-ISR TFT Digital Monitor
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

To attach the bracket to a Provision-ISR TFT digital monitor, locate the headrest cover on the back of the monitor and prise it open with a flathead screwdriver.


Once the headrest backcover has been removed, locate the groove in the back of your TFT monitor.


Loosen the square nut on the bracket and then slide it up the groove in the back of the monitor.


Rotate the knob clockwise to tighten the nut and fix the bracket to the monitor.

entry.title: How To Back Up Recorded Footage from a Provision-ISR Video Recorder
entry.content:
How To Back Up Recorded Footage on a Provision-ISR DVR/NVR
Insert a USB drive into one of the USB ports on the DVR/NVR.

Select “Backup” from the main menu.

Locate footage by searching between a Start Time and an End Time.
For example, if an incident occurred in the early morning, a safe bet is a Start Time of 00:00:00 (midnight) and an End Time of 09:00:00 (9am) of the given date.

You can also Search.



Select the Event and click Backup.


In “Save File Type” you can select either DVR or AVI.
DVR is encoded with a proprietary codec that can be played only with the Backup Player.  This open complies with Victorian legal requirements for admissibility of video evidence.
AVI is an open format and does not comply with Victorian legal requirements for admissibility of video evidence, but for the purposes of reviewing footage and extracting stills it is very convenient.

Convert

Super Player, which can be bundled with the DVR export option, has an option to convert footage to AVI.

entry.title: How To Use a Television as a Spot Monitor with a Provision-ISR Video Recorder
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

Connect a BNC cable to the CVBS (“Spot”) port on the back of your Provision-ISR video recorder:

Attach a BNC-to-RCA

Connect a BNC cable to the CVBS Port:

Spot Monitor Port == BNC == BNC-RCA Adaptor == RCA Port
Spot Monitor Port == BNC == BNC-HDMI Adaptor == HDMI Port

entry.title: Provision-ISR NVR without PoE
entry.content:
A non-PoE NVR needs to be connected to a router (or some other device that functions as a DHCP server) in order to find IP cameras. 
Connected to monitor, either by HDMI or VGA, this works perfectly as a closed-circuit system if internet access is not required.




If the router serves also as your site's internet gateway, you can set up remote access through port forwarding or Provision-ISR's secure and robust P2P server.


And if your site has a dynamic external IP address, as opposed to a static external IP address, your Provision-ISR installer can easily set up a secure DDNS for you.
Thank you for your post. It is amazing and wonderful to visit your Blog. SAFEALL Cheapest Video Door Phones

entry.title: How To Adjust a Provision-ISR AHD Camera Light Sensor
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

Provision-ISR AHD cameras are made to switch seamlessly between day and night modes to give excellent coverage around the clock.


There are times when the settings need to be adjusted.


Two occasional problems an installer might face are these:
  1. The camera switches to Day mode (and then back to Night mode) during the night.
  2. The camera switches to Night mode during the day.


If you are using a 1080p Provision-ISR AHD recorder, the camera settings can be adjusted from the DVR itself; if you are using a 720p recorder, you’ll have to use the joystick on the camera itself.


OSD MENU INSTRUCTIONS


Press the camera joystick to summon the OSD menu.
Go to Option 5: Day&Night


  • If the option is "EXT", click to go to the sensor sub-menu.
  • If the option is not "EXT", toggle left or right until you arrive at "EXT".  The other options are as follows:
Once you are in the Day&Night sub-menu, you will see these default settings:




Toggle left or right to adjust the delay.
  • Day to Night (D-N)
  • Night to Day (N-D)
If you have a camera switching frequently to day mode at night, increase the N-D delay to 6 seconds.
If you have a camera switching frequently to night mode during the day, increase the D-N to 6 seconds.


Here is an example:


You can also set the camera to remain on "color" mode, even at night:




Or black-and-white mode, regardless of the amount of light available:



But the default setting is "auto":

Nice system, unfortunately the browser ability to run the cameras on anything except IE11 is a very bad FAIL! The plug-in for Firefox does NOT work and when trying to use Chrome the same plug-in with Mozilla registry entries wants to run. Doesn't work. As for Firefox, NO popup screen appears after the plug-in has been run and Firefox reopened. As said, great system but if this is the extent of your technical support it make a great system totally useless if you have an issue. Jas N asked a question 14 months ago and looks like they are still waiting for an answer. Great support guys.....NOT! Also, what's with the Chinese characters in the Remark lines in the setup.cmd?

entry.title: How To Remotely View Provision-ISR CCTV in Your Browser
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

You can log into a Provision-ISR DVR or NVR or even a stand-alone IP camera via Internet Explorer or Firefox on Windows, or Safari on MacOSX.

Windows

Internet Explorer

Make sure that your Security Settings allow the ActiveX plug-in.
Next, go to the external IP or DDNS address provided by your installer.
You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.

Firefox

Your CCTV system’s web address will take you to a light-blue page with a large download button and a refresh button.  Click the download button to download the file Webclient.exe.
Close Firefox.
Open Windows Explorer, locate the downloaded Webclient.exe and run it.
A terminal window will open briefly and then close again.
Re-open Firefox and return to your CCTV system’s web address.  Now you should receive a pop-up notification asking for permission to run an ActiveX control.
Finally, refresh the page.
You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.

Mac OSX

Safari is the only browser on Mac OSX that consistently allows the necessary ActiveX controls for logging into a Provision-ISR system, although it is theoretically possible on Firefox too.
Instructions for Mac OSX will be made available soon.

Linux


There is currently no way to log into a Provision-ISR system via a browser on Linux, as the ActiveX controls necessary are not available for Linux.  Your best bet is to run Internet Explorer or Firefox in a Windows Virtualbox.  A theoretical possibility is to run Internet Explorer in Wine, but this has not been done to date with any success.

entry.title: How To Get Essential Information About Your Network
entry.content:
How To Get Essential Information About Your Network
Click the Windows logo in the bottom left to bring up the Windows Search tool.

Type “run”.

In the Windows Search Tool, type “cmd” in the Run program and click “OK”.


This will open a command line terminal.  At the command prompt, type “ipconfig /all”.


Note every instance of the following, it may vary between adapters:
  • Default gateway
  • DHCP Server
  • DNS Servers

To copy all of the information from the terminal:
  1. Right-click in the terminal screen to bring up the context menu
  2. Left-click “Select All”


Then press Enter to copy the selected text.


Saving the Information

  1. Click the Windows icon.
  2. Type Notepad.
  3. Left-click the Notepad Desktop App icon.


Paste the contents into a Notepad window and save


Copy the same text.


Send the email to your support representative or security installer.

entry.title: How to Adjust a Provision-ISR AHD Camera with Control over Coax (CoC)
entry.content:
How To Adjust a Provision-ISR AHD Camera via Control over Coax (CoC)
Certain Provision-ISR AHD cameras are equipped with CoC (Control over Coax), which gives you access to the full camera menu from the browser.

Please check with your local Provision-ISR supplier to make sure that this option is available for your AHD camera.

The camera used in this demonstration is IV-390AHD37.

Step One: Open the Browser Interface.

Here are full instructions for logging into your Provision-ISR DVR via the browser.


STEP TWO: Bring up the Camera’s PTZ Settings

  1. Bring up the full-screen view of your desired camera.


  1. Select the PTZ settings from the right-hand sidebar.

STEP THREE: Summon the Camera Settings Menu

Click the Plus sign next to the IRIS icon to summon the camera settings menu.

STEP FOUR: Navigate the Camera Settings Menu

The PTZ controls serve as the Control over Coax interface.

entry.title: How To Find Out The Default Gateway On Windows
entry.content:
How To Find Out The Default Gateway On Windows
Click the Windows logo in the bottom left to bring up the Windows Search tool.

Type “run”.


In the Windows Search Tool, type “cmd” in the Run program and click “OK”.


This will open a command line terminal.  At the command prompt, type “ipconfig”.


Look for the default gateway.  In a simple network, this will also be the address of the router.

entry.title: RSS Feeds
entry.content:
If you would like to subscribe to specific topics covered by this blog, here are RSS feeds to suit your tastes.  Simply copy the hyperlink and feed it into your RSS reader.

The Odessia

Anything and everything that pertains to The Odessia, a fantasy novel about an adventurous young woman and her feline companion.

RSS Feed:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default/-/theodessia?alt=rss

FAI Journal

A record of my thoughts, experiences, experiments, successes, and setbacks in my pursuit of mobility, flexibility, fitness, strength, balance, and agility.

RSS Feed:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default/-/faijournal?alt=rss

Reflections

Thoughts and musings on whatever comes to mind, which one way or another does not pertain to the other two topics.  I suspect most of it will have to do with cooking.

RSS Feed: 
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default/-/reflections?alt=rss
